title: Business News:  Corporate Watch
text:
LUMBER LIQUIDATORS

Home-Improvement

Projects Lift Profit

Lumber Liquidators Holdings Inc. said its profit rose for the fourth quarter as consumers continued improving their homes during the Covid-19 pandemic, though it said uncertainty and supply-chain volatility remain.

The Toano, Va., hardwood-flooring retailer posted net income of $31.1 million, compared with $16.4 million a year earlier. Net sales rose 11% to $304.2 million. Same-store sales rose 11% for the quarter.

The company said it wouldn't provide 2021 guidance due to the uncertainty.

-- Dave Sebastian

---

DINE BRANDS

Restaurant Chain

Swings to a Loss

Dine Brands Global Inc. swung to a loss in the fourth quarter as sales dropped at Applebee's and IHOP restaurants.

The company reported a loss of $1.56 million, compared with a profit of $27.4 million. Total revenue fell to $196 million from $227.5 million. Domestic same-restaurant sales fell 30% at IHOP and 18% at Applebee's. At the end of 2020, more than 400 dining rooms were closed because of government mandates, but now almost all of Applebee's 1,600 dining rooms are open.

-- Allison Prang

---

EPIC GAMES

Maker of 'Fall Guys'

Game Is Purchased

Epic Games Inc. acquired the development company behind "Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout, a deal it said would help bolster talent across the company.

Terms of the deal for Tonic Games Group weren't disclosed. Epic, based in Cary, N.C., is a privately held company that created the popular "Fortnite" game and has tussled with Apple Inc. over how the iPhone maker operates its App Store.

Tonic describes itself as a games development and publishing company with around 300 employees.

It develops new games, brings them to market and invests in independent game developers.

-- Micah Maidenberg

---

RALPH LAUREN

Rentals Offered

On Low-Cost Brand

Ralph Lauren Corp. is launching a rental service for its lower-price Lauren Ralph Lauren brand.

The service will cost $125 a month, and shoppers will have the option to purchase rental items.

Rental clothing services have come under pressure during the pandemic, as shoppers stayed home and needed fewer clothes for events.

But retail executives expect demand to rebound in the second half as vaccines roll out and Covid-19 infection rates decrease.

-- Suzanne Kapner

---

LYFT

Use of Rideshare

Rose in February

Lyft Inc.'s average daily rideshare rides in February increased 4% from January.

The company said rideshare ride volume during the week ended Feb. 28 was a record for 2021 and the company's best week since March 2020.

Lyft said it continues to expect average daily rideshare volume in the first quarter of 2021 to exceed that number from the fourth quarter of 2020.

Following the news Tuesday afternoon, shares of Lyft rose 4.6% in after-hours trading.

-- Stephen Nakrosis
